The coefficient of $x^{50}$ in
\[(1 + x)^{1000} + 2x (1 + x)^{999} + 3x^2 (1 + x)^{998} + \dots + 1001x^{1000}\]can be expressed in the form $\binom{n}{k}.$  Find the smallest possible value of $n + k.$
inference:
We are interested in the coefficient of $x^{50}$ in
\[(1+x)^{1000} + 2x(1+x)^{999} + 3x^2(1+x)^{998} + \dots + 1001x^{1000}.\]
This is a finite geometric series,
\begin{align*} \sum_{k=0}^{1000} (k+1)x^k (1+x)^{1000-k} &= \sum_{k=0}^{1000} (k+1)x^k \sum_{j=0}^{1000-k} \binom{1000-k}{j}x^j \\ &= \sum_{k=0}^{1000} (k+1) \sum_{j=0}^{1000-k} \binom{1000-k}{j} x^{k+j}. \end{align*}We want the coefficient of $x^{50}$. This happens when $k+j = 50$.

The coefficient of $x^{50}$ is
\begin{align*} &\sum_{k=0}^{50} (k+1) \binom{1000-k}{50-k} \\ &= \sum_{k=0}^{50} (k+1) \binom{1000-k}{1000-k-(50-k)} \\ &= \sum_{k=0}^{50} (k+1) \binom{1000-k}{950+k}. \end{align*}Let $k=50-l$. Then
\begin{align*} &\sum_{l=0}^{50} (50-l+1) \binom{1000-(50-l)}{950+(50-l)} \\ &= \sum_{l=0}^{50} (51-l) \binom{950+l}{950+l}. \end{align*}Also, the sum can be written as
\[ \sum_{k=0}^{1000} (k+1) \binom{1000-k}{50-k} = \sum_{k=0}^{50} (k+1) \binom{1000-k}{50-k} \]
If $m=1000-k$ and $n=50-k$, then $k = 1000 - m$ and $n = 50 - (1000-m) = m - 950$, and we are interested in
\begin{align*} \sum_{m=950}^{1000} (1001-m) \binom{m}{m-950}. \end{align*}
This is the sum
\[ \binom{1001}{50} \times \sum_{k=0}^{50} \binom{1000-k}{50-k} (k+1) = \binom{1001}{50}. \]
From the Hockey Stick Identity,
\begin{align*} \sum_{j=0}^{n} (j+1) \binom{m}{j} = (n+1) \binom{m+1}{n+1}. \end{align*}So, the coefficient is $\binom{1001}{51}.$

Final Answer: $\boxed{1051}$
